pr_title: Issue 4927 deleteKeyValueTableTest fails for InMemoryKVTableStore when using KVTOperationContext

timeline.bodyText: why is this being changed? what was wrong with taking the kvt from the context?
timeline.author: shiveshr

replies.bodyText:
There is no benefit in taking KVT from context in case of InMemoryStore as all data is already in memory.
When using KVT from context, the KVTable object is available in the context though it is removed from the scope. Besides it has State="Deleting" which causes the isDeleted() method to never compete.
replies.author: pbelgundi

replies.bodyText:
what is the delete method doing? perhaps it should be implemented such that it marks the entry as deleted and removes the entry from the map.
that way context will be able to get the correct value as well.

replies.bodyText: It should all fall in place once Scopes are implemented correctly in InMemoryKVTMetadataStore.

replies.author: pbelgundi

replies.bodyText:
creating an immutable map each time its accessed here is costly as it will make a copy.
instead you can use Collections.unmodifiableMap which actually creates a wrapper decoration on the map which prohibits any changes to the map
replies.author: shiveshr

replies.bodyText:
actually i dont see you returning an immutable map.
immutable map is one in which you cannot add/remove/replace any entries.
setting the field as final doesnt make it immutable, it just means that field cannot be assigned a different value. but the object that the field refers to can still be immutable, as is the case here.

replies.bodyText: I'd prefer to have it initialized here to avoid NPEs.
replies.author: pbelgundi

replies.bodyText: no i mean init in constructor
replies.author: shiveshr

replies.bodyText: Construction initialization is good for usecases where the values used in building the object need to be passed to the constructor. Initializing at the time of declaration also takes away the need to synchronize the constructor and I don't see any downsides with initializing it this way.
replies.author: pbelgundi

replies.bodyText:
no downside, just consistency as other objects are initialized in the constructor.
Also constructor is implicitly synchronized and you dont need to synchronize a constructor.
replies.author: shiveshr

replies.bodyText: Ok.
replies.author: pbelgundi

timeline.bodyText: it is more consistent to initialize this in the contructor as all other fields are also initialized in the constructor.
timeline.author: shiveshr

replies.bodyText: also, all other fields are non final. as we set them to null in deleteScope. though logically that doesnt really give us anything. but since that is the pattern being used for all other objects, i would suggest we keep the same pattern for this field too.
replies.author: shiveshr

replies.bodyText: I don't like the idea of having data members point to null values and initializing them upfront or in the constructor helps avoid NPEs
replies.author: pbelgundi

replies.bodyText:
we should never be accessing a "deleted" scope object.
The purpose of setting all fields in the scope object to null should not cause NPE. And if it does, it would point to a bug that should be fixed.
replies.author: shiveshr

replies.bodyText: Whenever possible, I'd want to avoid null references to class data members in the code, as a good coding practice...
